page.title: 14NATURE IN SANTON DOWNHAM (2)
page.content: Although few plants grow under the pine trees, the fringe areas and river banks are worth studying. In Breckland as a whole are to be found Spanish Catchfly, Spring Speedwell, Hounds Tongue, Meadow Saxifrage and Mahonia Japonica. Also in certain areas on walls and gravestones many lichens and mosses occur. With help from the F.C., 4 kinds of deer roam the forest (Red, Fallow, Roe and Muntjac). They are herded to prevent damage to young trees and save them from poachers. There are many Grey Squirrels and few Red ones. Moles and Mice are common as are the riverside mammals. The remaining Rabbits and Hares have to be controlled although Myxamotosis aided the depletion of Rabbits.
